comments.commentBody:
I work for a computer company that is serious about computer security. If they found out that I had done the company's work on a computer that I shared with another person, I would get hauled into HR, and if I didn't get fired, they would demand that I get that computer back and let them scrub it. Of course they made sure that I knew in advance that I shouldn't do something like that.

That leaves me with two thoughts: 1) Is the State Department's security so flakey that the people that work don't know the the fundamentals of computer security? and 2) This should be more of a problem for Huma Abedin than for Hillary. I presume that computer will contain mostly copies of emails that existed on other computers as well. They are not likely to learn anything new about Hillary from the emails there.

Finally, it is beyond ironic that the first successful female presidential candidate is influenced by a philanderer, a predator, and a pervert. It's making the rest of us look bad.

The statistics that originally made polling scientific are useless in the age of the cell phone. Polling has become akin to astrology or Ouija boards—fun party gimmicks but not very dependable for suggesting what the future is going to bring.

The “dean of sampling,” Phillip Hauser invented a concept he called “chunk sampling;” which he defined as “a slice of the population dictated by convenience rather than representativeness.” I think the public would be better served with “chunks” that they knew weren’t real rather than with a bunch of charts and graphs pretending to be scientific.

If the polls start showing Trump leading on Monday and on Wednesday he’s lost the election, what a cacophony we’ll be subject to.

Until the "quants" come up with new sampling techniques to replace the 19th century ones, polling results should be exhibited with "caution" designations “polling could be dangerous to your future.”

replies.commentBody: A vote for the lesser of two evils is no matter how you twist or turn, still a vote for evil.    Time for a new broom to seep the rot out of Wash., DC.

People forget Hillary Clinton is a 69-year old person with limited or any IT experience. Somehow I doubt she cooked up the server idea in the first place. She may have asked staff to come up with a email plan - but I doubt she looked at her staff and said order me my own personal server. She may have asked for a solution be able to send both personal and government emails without the private emails becoming public record.

Governments tend to run behind in technology and back in 2008/2009 and many in upper management were just starting to use email on a regular basis. I mean Collin Powel was using AOL - anyway - the government tends to over classify documents - just about any document will carry some form of classification.

comments.commentBody: It's interesting how nothing has changed after Hillary and Donald were nominated. The news wants to highlight every wikileaks revelation and every tape as though this is the last straw. That's become their job I guess. But at the end of the day Hillary is still a vulnerable person who is unfamiliar with proper internet protocol and Donald has one finger on the nuclear button and the other up some woman's skirt while trying to sell his snake oil to some poor hurting soul who'll buy anything. Hillary, in my opinion, is still the lesser evil of the two candidates and I can't wait for all this nonsense, which is the real reason for America's decline, comes to an end.

replies.commentBody: Just what is behind the rationale to support the Walmart stooges from Arkansas?

comments.commentBody: Very interesting read...many thanks for clearly describing what I think most of us felt.  What troubles me most about this election is the way the 'scandals' and 'controversies' about Hillary Clinton have been blown way out of proportion.  How does one equate using a private email server to being a sexual predator?  How do you suggest impropriety with the dealing of the Clinton Foundation with the demonstrated abuses of donated funds from the Trump Charity?  How does the many years of dedication to women's and children's issues be dismissed while years of self-enrichment on the backs of workers not be highlighted?  The decision in this election is clear; what isn't clear to me is the intellectual process (or lack thereof) being employed to justify a vote for Trump...it is scary.

Via Comey, Trump will undoubtedly solidify his advantage with his already loyal followers and possibly entice waverers to climb aboard his bandwagon. Hillary will suffer more damage among those groups already disinclined to vote for her. Some of her followers will feel uncomfortable with the limelight she has been put in, and they will wonder what's going on.

You've got to hand it to Comey. He probably doesn't care what happens to him as long as Trump or, at the minimum, the down-ballot GOP candidates, win. A hero of the Alt-Right? Right! A true-blue American dedicated to lawn order and democracy. Nah.

Keep your eyes on Comey's future. The party and/or Trump will reward him for his bravery. Bottom line? FBI Director J. Edgar Comey fell on his sword for the sake of his party. Whatever happens to him, he and others see his actions as dedicated to blocking Hillary. For that he will win the undying love of the GOP, Tea Partyers, and as-yet-unidentified foreign interest, Da, Tovarich?

James Comey - you had to struggle with your "conscience" to be the evil SOB you are?

Well the article gives a little hope, but estimate the thuggishness of the GOP at your peril. They tend to win the ones they should've lost - by any means necessary.

By any means necessary. None of us should forget this nor become complacent.

I hate to say it but Trump was right......he could shoot somebody in New York's 5th avenue in front of everybody and his supporters will stick with him. I think the nickname "deplorables" falls short for this people.

What is terribly wrong with all of this is that in some places such as Texas white kids have started to warn "brown" classmates (mostly from Pakistani-India descents and even some Asian kids) that when Trump wins they will be deported.

That's the heritage of this con man, hatred, racism, intolerance, bigotry and yet 40% of the electorate find that acceptable....
A lady sitting next to me on the recent airplane ride I was on made me  realize just  how committed many Trump supporters are. Don't write them off. JGAIA

Problem for the Trump campaign is that they have been so over-the-top on their "lock her up" rhetoric that there's no way to ratchet things up further at this point. If their message that she's corrupt, blah blah blah, hasn't gotten through to swing voters at this point, then it's unlikely that this most recent episode will have all that much of an impact. In other words, if you've got your message amped up to 11 already, there's no room left on the dial to go higher (even if you're Spinal Tap!)

If Trump had been a more reasonable and rational candidate all along, then he might have been able to make hay of these revelations, but, in that case, he wouldn't be Donald Trump.

Perhaps just the sheer mention of FBI + emails + Hillary will have an impact on some low-information voters, but, as the article I think rightly notes, unlikely to change the fundamentals.

Republican operatives more generally probably realize that, even with this highly mushy and ambiguous new revelation, they can't beat her, but they are also determined to delivery as many wounds as possible to her on her way to the oval office, because they are, as we know, such a public spirited and patriotic bunch.

replies.commentBody: The Clinton resume, the impeachment, on and on and on.    Why support the baggage from Arkansas?

comments.commentBody: Nations are governed by the men and women who are no more perfect than the citizens. If you are looking for saints you won't find them in Washington or even in Vatican. So the task is to pick person who is  relatively the most qualified to be President. Donald Trump is definitely not that individual.

No, Mr Trump is not fit to be President. But he is the "canary in the cage" who shocked me out of complacency - and made me realize that his supporters WERE fit to be heard - long before now.

They're scared they won't keep their jobs. They can't save enough money to pay for health care or put aside retirement funds. Shame on us, Democrats and Republicans alike, for waiting till Trump came along to pay attention.

This is different. Its substance is durable. It signifies that HC, like her mastastasizing emails, would be a cancer on the presidency.

These emails are but one small sample of what is out there. Her purloined letters are doubtless in the hands of every malefactor and pimple-faced prepubescent hacker extant. Can you say "blackmailable"?

The analog crook didn't have a clue. Spoliation of digital evidence is a bit more complicated than, say, squirrelling away Rose Law Firm hard copy in the WH residence until the statutes of limitations have run. Neera Tanden hit it on the head (oops) when she said to Podesta: "It worries me more that she doesn’t …know what planet we're on”

We don't need another round of the corrupt and dangerous Clintons. And we don't need another Nixon.

replies.commentBody: It's not the groping, it's the fascism from the Orange Fuhrer that should worry everyone--threats to lock up political opponents, threats to shut down the press, threats to sue anyone telling the truth (so ironic from one who doesn't even get into the same time zone as the truth, between ten and thirty times a day), threats to Muslims and Hispanics, the celebration of the white supremacist coalition.

comments.commentBody: America has been desensitized to sexual indiscretions. This is the only way that Hillary could be allowed to run with Bill Clinton, the rapist, as her first gentleman. In my opinion, I would not change my vote away from Trump unless at least 1500 women come forward between now and election date. America cares more about Hillary's corruption than what Donald trump may have said, or whom he might have groped 15 years ago.

replies.commentBody:
I am amazed out how willing people are to tune out the myriad disqualifying behaviors of Donal Trump, there's lots of discussion about how the disgusting behavior towards women 'wasn't really that bad or relevant', have people forgotten his mockery of a handicapped reporter, his derision of brave Muslim parents whose sone gave his life to defend our country? do they not watch any of the exposes on small businesses his busines machinations ripped off.
Hillary will face worse behavior than was delivered to Obama from republicans in congress, we need to wash them out too with this election

comments.commentBody:
Usually I don't look forward to Nov. 1, because it means Halloween (still a favorite holiday, despite it having been loved almost to death in the 1990s & 2000s) is over.

This year, back in September I *was* looking forward to Nov. 1, with the hope that it would be the end of "October surprises." The way this most tawdry, unfairly skewed, and demoralizing election has been going, however, I'm sure we'll be in for "November surprises," as well, probably right up until Nov. 8.

If Clinton nevertheless wins, I'm sure we'll be in for the same kind of howling from losing side & obstructionism in Congress, that we saw during Obama's eight years, except worse. Worse because it'll be adding insult to the "injury" of the previous 8 years, and because the revulsion sexist and misogynist people (especially sexist & misogynist men) will feel about a woman in the White House will, I believe, be even stronger than the revulsion racist people have felt about a "black" man in the White House. (Obama is in fact bi-racial, of course, but he's been perceived as "black" by not only by racist whites, but by African-Americans, and indeed in our culture today, because of our history & the non-scientific nature of social dynamics, bi-racial people do generally experience their lives as "black" rather than "white.")

If Trump wins, among other things, we can expect the lunatic fringe of his supporters to be quite ugly in their exultations, perhaps even uglier than they would've been in defeat.

Did the Democratic and Republican parties fail to nominate candidates that were properly vetted for the 2016 campaign or, because scrutiny is so high, and the negative campaigning so keen, were these candidates doomed to fall short of our expectations?
Partisanship is so high and passionate that the bases of both parties really do not care what the flaws of their respective candidates are just so long as they perceive that their POV is represented. In summary, if I like Hillary's stance on trade or abortion, I don't care about emails and, if I like Donald's stance on building walls and banning Muslim travel, I don't care about his misogyny.
Pedrito

Enough with another email diversion.  It's a rehash of what we already know.  What we don't know is what Donald paid (or didn't pay) in taxes, to support this government he'd like to be the leader of.  Let's see the tax returns.

In Australia any news articles about Trump that have comments sections have similar dogged and irrational DT supporters that proportionately outnumber the anti- Trump ones. In fact it is worse here. Trump is a comments section running for President. Rational people here feel frustrated because we are deeply affected by the result yet cannot vote or donate. Worse is trying to convince the dogged DT supporters. We had an occurence here of an Indian immigrant bus driver in Brisbane doused with fuel and set alight. That is hardly mentioned here. Had an Indian immolated a white driver, the outrage would be palpable. This was done by a nutter of course. who may not have done it had not if the atmosphere not been permeated by expressed bigotry legitimised by the likes of Trump just saying what they feel like saying. Take a look at Adeaide Now- a Murdoch owned tabloid. Actually Rupert started in Adelaide. It is hard to find an anti-Trump comment. They make the usual defences of the indefensible. Any normal candidate would not survive the Stern/Billy Bush tapes, let alone Donald's outrageous comments about dating a "voluptuous" daughter and a prepubescent child (when she grows up). How does this guy stay in the race?
What is he selling that is so darn attractive to the geniuses who like him? He does not tell it how it is at all- he tells it how it isn't. The appeal is that he legitimises saying what you feel like no matter how hurtful it is to women and various minorities.

HRC has sent classified emails from her unauthorized server and destroyed evidence which is a felony.  This election is like, What Ever Happened to Baby "Hillary"?  Mr. Comey has been bound and gagged but his letter begging for help from the voter has been intercepted.  I feel like screaming at HRC "Butcha are Blanche!"  YOU are a felon!

Thank you Nate for calming liberals and Dems with your reassuring numbers. "Hyposteria," a condition caused by the bacterium H. Hyposterium, also known as Hillary's Pneumonia, results in confusion, dizziness, and fits of hysteria when the sufferer is confronted by conflicting facts, has caused many on the left to make hypocritical, asinine and inane statements. This illness appears to be highly contagious and is spreading fast according to the CDC. Former Senate Majority Leader, Harry Reid, just caught a nasty case of hyposteria which resulted in him sending an irate, irrational and rambling missive to FBI Director Comey. Even some of your colleagues, most notably Charles Blow, have come down with Hillary's Pneumonia. In Mr. Blow's case, delerium led him to write a nonsensical column about genitalia. And if the rumors are true, it looks like Paul Krugman may be on his back for weeks.  Your column could not have arrived at a better time. Thanks to your work--I like to think of it as chicken soup for the liberal soul--you may have saved thousands (sorry, I can't remember the current readership of The Times) from catching hyposteria. God bless.

It is most unfortunate that an impartial federal agency has been drawn into impacting election influence in the eleventh hour.

That said, the impact of this would have had minimal impact had we had stronger nominees by our two major political parties. As it is, both nominees carry unprecedented baggage and insinuations become catalysts that affect cross party and undecided votes beyond reasonable proportions.

If we had nominees of better character, such as Michael Bloomberg, Colin Powell, John Kasich, Mitt Romney, these last minute "gotchas" would have minimal impact upon the election.

"Get Ready for Another Swing in the Polls"
Being a professor in government politics I have instructed my P101 students to write a 10 page summary on the Swing issues. One of my students, I admit a bit of a brownnoser, complained that 10 pages is not enough.

"[T]he same history makes it harder to argue that a change in the polls would represent a lasting shift in the race."

Unfortunately, with 8 days to go, the shift doesn't need to be "lasting."

Which means that the interference in this election by outsiders (Wikileaks, Comey, Russia), all against Clinton and to Trump's advantage, may indeed sway the election. Even if the U.S. were *not* a beacon of democracy and the rule of law (starting with our constitution) to the world, even if the U.S. were not the most powerful and technologically developed country on earth, this would be outrageous.

If *anything* is reminiscent of Watergate (with its burglars working for the infamous Committee to Re-Elect the President, or CREEP), its these one-sided attacks on our electoral process, the very heart of our democracy.

Remember the story of the boy who cried wolf? That is the same with Clinton's emails. People are immune to hearing about them. They already don't care.

I kinda feel bad for Trump supporters. Articles like this are unkind to them because it is setting them up to think that Trump can win. It's like in Peanuts, Lucy taunting Charlie Brown to try to kick the football just one more time.
I wonder what interesting nuggets we'd be learning about Trump if Wikileaks (and Russia) had leaked Trump's information even half as much as they've leaked Clinton's.
This proves Clinton has something to hide. I suggest she has many things that she's keeping secret. And yeah, it is a big deal!!
